result.markdown:
--- title: "Does Town Size Influence Youth Employment Opportunities?" author: "Arun Krishnasamy" date: "2024-08-13" categories: [Post] --- ::: {.cell} ::: ## Problem Description The belief that moving to larger cities leads to better career opportunities has been a longstanding narrative. However, this study examines whether young adults, specifically 19-year-olds, actually fare better in terms of employment in smaller towns compared to bigger cities. This blog post explores whether the size of a town impacts youth employment rates and how this understanding could reshape career planning for young adults. ## Data Description The dataset used in this analysis is sourced from the [TidyTuesdayR](https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday) project. It includes employment data for 19-year-olds across different UK towns, categorized by size. The key variables include: - **Employment Rate**: The proportion of 19-year-olds employed with earnings above 0. - **Size Classification**: Categorizes the towns into "Small", "Medium", and "Large". ### Data Cleaning To prepare the data for analysis, the following cleaning steps were performed: - Filtered out missing or non-numeric employment data. - Recoded the town size categories, excluding outliers like "Inner London BUA". ::: {.cell} ::: The data was analyzed using statistical techniques, including ANOVA and Tukey's HSD post-hoc test. The analysis revealed significant differences in employment rates across town sizes. The box plot @fig-boxplot below shows the distribution of employment rates across different town sizes. Small towns tend to have a higher median employment rate for 19-year-olds, suggesting that starting one's career in a smaller town might offer better job opportunities. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![The distribution of employment rates at age 19 across different town sizes. Cities have the lowest median and largest variation, while Small Towns have the highest variation but a median similar to Medium and Large Towns.](revised_blog_post_files/figure-html/fig-boxplot-1.png){#fig-boxplot width=672} ::: ::: To quantify the differences, the table @tbl-employment-rate below summarizes the average employment rates for each town size. ::: {#tbl-employment-rate .cell tbl-cap='The average employment rates for 19-year-olds across different town sizes. Small towns exhibit the highest average employment rates, while cities show the lowest.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Size_Classification Average_Employment_Rate
City 42.6
Large Towns 46.5
Medium Towns 48.7
Small Towns 50.1
````` ::: ::: The ANOVA test further confirmed that the differences between groups are statistically significant, with small towns offering better employment prospects for young adults compared to large cities. ::: {#tbl-anova .cell tbl-cap='ANOVA Results for the Effect of Town Size Classification on Employment Rates at Age 19'} ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 2 × 6 term df sumsq meansq statistic p.value 1 Size_Classification 3 2066. 689. 15.7 5.26e-10 2 Residuals 1095 48003. 43.8 NA NA ``` ::: ::: While the ANOVA test confirmed that there are significant differences between the town size groups in terms of employment rates, it does not tell us which groups differ from each other. To further investigate these pairwise differences, a Tukey HSD post-hoc test was conducted. The Tukey HSD test results @tbl-posthoc provide insight into the specific town size pairs that show significant differences in employment rates: ::: {#tbl-posthoc .cell tbl-cap='Tukey HSD Post-hoc Test results showing pairwise comparisons between town sizes. Small and Medium Towns exhibit significantly higher employment rates than Cities and Large Towns.'} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
contrast estimate conf.low conf.high adj.p.value
Large Towns-City 3.87 -0.530 8.28 0.107
Medium Towns-City 6.14 2.021 10.27 0.001
Small Towns-City 7.52 3.450 11.59 0.000
Medium Towns-Large Towns 2.27 0.237 4.31 0.022
Small Towns-Large Towns 3.65 1.723 5.57 0.000
Small Towns-Medium Towns 1.38 0.228 2.52 0.011
````` ::: ::: - **Medium Towns vs. City:** A significant difference was observed, with Medium Towns having a higher employment rate than Cities (p = 0.001). - **Small Towns vs. City:** A significant difference was also found, with Small Towns outperforming Cities (p < 0.001). - **Small Towns vs. Large Towns:** Small Towns showed significantly higher employment rates than Large Towns (p < 0.001). - **Medium Towns vs. Large Towns:** Medium Towns also had a significantly higher employment rate than Large Towns (p = 0.022). - **Small Towns vs. Medium Towns:** A modest but significant difference was found between Small and Medium Towns (p = 0.011). However, Large Towns vs. City did not show a statistically significant difference (p = 0.107), indicating that employment rates between these two groups are relatively similar. To visualize these differences, the following plot @fig-HSD shows the confidence intervals for each comparison: ::: {.cell} ::: This analysis challenges the conventional belief that larger cities are better for starting careers. In fact, smaller towns provide better employment opportunities for young people aged 19. This finding has important implications for both career planning and policy development. As urban areas face increasing competition and saturation, young adults may find more success by considering opportunities in smaller towns. ONS. (2023). Why Do Children and Young People in Smaller Towns Do Better Academically Than Those in Larger Towns? [Office for National Statistics](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/educationandchildcare/articles/whydochildrenandyoungpeopleinsmallertownsdobetteracademicallythanthoseinlargertowns/2023-07-25). R for Data Science Online Learning Community, 2024. TidyTuesday: A weekly data project aimed at the R ecosystem. GitHub repository
